doc/source/2008.rst.message:
Mysql InnoDB Cluster TLS communication
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

TLS communication between Mysql InnoDB Cluster and its cloud clients is now
supported. Previously, TLS was only enabled for inter-MySQL client
communication by way of a self-signed certificate.

Due to the circular dependency between the vault and mysql-innodb-cluster
applications to set this up, the enablement of this feature can only be done
post-deployment (once vault has been initialised and has a root Certificate
Authority).

Enable database TLS communication with this relation:

.. code-block:: none

   juju add-relation mysql-innodb-cluster:certificates vault:certificates

A few things:

1. Unlike glance, which mounts its NFS shares on the host using an entry in fstab, cinder itself issues the mount commands. Therefore, the '_netdev' and 'bg' options are not relevant (and 'bg' not desirable).

2. The sample-env generator controls this files contents, and  the contents comes from the THT parameter default values (I expect the tox unit test will fail). Thus, you need to ensure the value listed here matches the one at [1]. So [1] also needs to be updated.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Have I this symbol backwards? '/dev/rbdN' is the real file. '/dev/rbd/{pool}/{device}' is the symlink.

that is not what is happening.

udev is present on the system (provided by systemd) but ceph-common pacakge is installed in the container so the udev rules are not viable on the host and are not executed.

the end result is the same but udev is still there.
I was imprecise in my wording. I meant when libvirt is deployed/running inside a container, as opposed to running outside of the container. Will update
or if the host is missing the udev rule because it doesn't have ceph-common installed

Yeah apologies I've been talking to Sean about this in the background and agree that longer term we need to burn down some of this debt and reliance on udev. I'm only suggesting the installation of ceph-common as a short term workaround in TripleO when users want to use local attach.

i dont think this patch exclues either adding the package to the host or altering os-brick to retrun the new path

i think we should remove all depency on udev created symplink form os bricks or nova over time as in a containerise world this is not viable and it even has multi distro implication as the udev rules might not always be the same.

i dont think we should install ceph-common on ooo hosts or kolla hosts for that matter.

i like the idea of os-brick returing the path and allso the idea of making this a singel call but i think it might make sense to do that as a followup.
Right, I'd rather resolve this by ensuring these rules are present on the host itself.

i am not ok with ooo deployting ceph-common.

i consider the instalation of addtion packages on the host that are not requried at runtime to be a potential vector for security vulnerablites on the host as it increase the attack surface.

this package may be safe but out side of documenting the need to install it i dont think we should regress the removal of it form the host by adding it again.

That means installing packages on the host, and we may just be running os-brick inside a container. In that case telling administrators that they need to install packages on the host kind of defeats the purpose of using containers.

As an example, Ember-CSI (uses cinderlib which uses os-brick)  is deployed on OpenShift/Kubernetes, and telling administrators that they have to install ceph-common in the host would not be a good thing.

This patch is my second preferred solution, my first choice is  if we fix the Nova-Brick interaction for encrypted volumes.

We can make os-brick return a new path in the decryptor's 'attach_volume' and get Nova to use that path instead of the one from the connector's call.

Alternatively we can make os-brick connectors' 'connect_volume' accept a 'do_decrypt=True' parameter.  Then os-brick takes care of everything in one go, returning the decrypted DM (if it's an encrypted volume) and Nova would no longer need to make a second call to decrypt the volume.

Oh, OK, since I didn't see any TripleO reference I though we were talking in general.
I'm OK with the fix being TripleO deploying ceph-common as wel as this patch being completed, as long as we (Nova-Cinder) figure out a nice and clean solution afterwards.

  self._execute('ln', '--symbolic', '--force',
                root_device, rbd_dev_path,
                root_helper=self._root_helper,

If we fix that we can not only forget about this patch, but we can also remove some additional code that exists in the iSCSI connector code.

/dev/rbdX will exist but not the /dev/rbd/ directory yes.
-1: Please move this to a privsep method instead of calling the command line.

According to the Oslo Privsep documentation that's not the right way to do it [1]:

  Privsep functions live in a specific privsep submodule (for example, nova.privsep for nova).

and:

  Contexts are defined in the privsep/__init__.py file.

Some projects may call the directory "privileged" instead of "privsep", but they are all following that recommendation: Nova, Cinder, Neutron, Zun, Ceilometer, Cyborg, etc.

[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.privsep/latest/user/index.html

yes the oslo docs are worng and nova cinder an neuton all are bad examples to follow for different reasons. this has come up at the PTG and on the mailing list several times

if you have not already read
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-March/013433.html
and http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/004358.html

as to why the approch taken in Nova and other project shoudl not be followed they are a good read.

if you look at the cyborg review in particalr you will notice i was ask to review and share some of the best practices
we have developed since the mistaks that were maind in nova,cinder and neutron ectra have come to light. 
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673957/16

cyborg more or less implemented 

it still has a singel context wich is bad but they jsut have not had peole to work on decomposing it into multiple contexts yet

https://github.com/openstack/cyborg/blob/e64bcd598ff924dab58c4c9e296bd10c4bde283f/cyborg/privsep/__init__.py#L20

but you will note that its scoped to the cyborg module and all of its sub modules.

it is used to create functions in the module where they are used, that are suffixed with privaldaged 

@cyborg.privsep.sys_admin_pctxt.entrypoint
def lspci_privileged():
    cmd = ['lspci', '-nnn', '-D']
    return processutils.execute(*cmd)

https://github.com/openstack/cyborg/blob/973716aa23d033df3a23aa2b34ce533f3f320c8f/cyborg/accelerator/drivers/aichip/huawei/ascend.py#L35-L38

anyway this is a spereate discussion but centrailised privldage fucntion encurages more generalised function that take arbratry args that can cause problems if they take user provided input. that is the main reason for haveing lots of small module local specific functions that are defined where they are used

we proably should actully use python to create the symlink instead fo calling ln too.

the privsep method shoudl ideally be defiend in this file also and takke the pool volume and root dev and constuct the rbd_dev_path internally passing in paths to privesep fucntions is an antipattern as is grouping them in a centralised module.

Yeah, we are in agreement, using Python code is precisely what I was suggesting in my comment.

As for including the privsep method here, with our current privsep contexts we can't write the method here, it must be under the cinder/privsep directory or the privsep server side will fail to execute.

We can either create the method as cinder/privsep/rbd.py (like we have for LVM) or create a new context for this specific connector (which iirc will create a new privsep service).

Of course we can also just create a class/static method in here that has the code and call it from cinder/privsep, but being a simple and reusable method like "create_symlink" it makes more sense to have it there.

actully i was suggestign that there should be a os-brick context at the os_brick modoule level that was used to allow privldaged function to be created in any submodule.

using centralised pirivsep fucntiosn leads to more generic privsep function that are less secure and tend to have more privladges then are requried.

you also dont want to have a large number of context in differeen modules with the same permissions as that wastes meory on the host for each deamon and in general resuced performance

so you want as set of privsep context with limited permissions at the root of the lib and use the approicate context when needed.

anyway i have not looked how os-bricks uses privesp but that is how it should be using it in my view.

specs/rocky/prometheus-plugin.rst.message:
I think that this driver is not a basic driver. 

As a perspective of 3rd party monitoring tool integration, this is similar to the zabbix plug-in. why don't you explain zabbix monitoring drvier?

Yes, they are. And, by definition, 'basic' here means that they just checking by ping responses and are not capable of doing more custom monitoring target.

I will explain Zabbix plugin in the Alternative section.
How will you support a variety of exporters automatically?

Depends on what kind of application you would deploy in a VNF, the Prometheus driver will download and install the exporter into that VNF. if that application is not supported yet, an exception will be raised.

Gererally, Prometheus uses pull method between server and client. will you modify it?

If your proposal workflow is not a same as a original prometheus, you should metion the flow clearly.

Yes, It's correct. I'm not sure about your question. What do you mean by modify?

Of course, It will be different because It needs to work with the monitoring driver. Sure, I will add more details about the workflow.

Prometheus server still uses the pull method for the supported applications (with existing exporter). For the unsupported applications, 

BTW, the workflow of this plugin is presented under Proposed changes section, not here. This is the problem and introduction.
I think these spec already supported by Zabbix plugin. Could you make it clear? except previous function.
This is just the list of the features. Of course it's supported by Zabbix plugin too. That's why I put Zabbix under the Alternatives section.

Yes. slightly.
I think it is better if you emphasize the goodness of this feature.
I think that it would be better if you can clearly define what new features this feature provide.
Is it a question?
Ok. I will update this in the coming patch.
It seems too many things/features from Prometheus side, Could you please mention the scope of BP. And what exporters are planned to support. Also mention the Actions on policies going to support.

The main concept of this blueprint is "Enable Tacker Monitoring both 
Containerized VNF and VM VNF".
So we will support following features:/
* Infrastructure monitoring (both containerized-vim and original-vim)
* Application monitoring (for now, only possible to VM applications)
* Collected data can be graphically displayed
* Custom trigger conditions can be set for alerting
Those which are not in the above list are not in our scope, and will not be
supported.

When it comes to exporters, we will support the following:
- Related to Infra monitoring
    * openstack-exporter (without VNFD)
    * node exporter (with VNFD)
    * cAdvisor / kube-state-metrics (without VNFD)
- Related to App monitoring
    * apache exporter (with VNFD)
    * mysql exporter (with VNFD)

Lastly, I'm not sure what the policy is. Do you mean the policy for example,
triggering alarms at certain cpu percentage?
If so, the alarm function will be supported. There is Alertmanager that 
manages those situations.
However, the Action is not the scope of this blueprint. Because Prometheus 
does not provide any action related function.

Thanks for explanation, please mention these scopes in spec.

>> Lastly, I'm not sure what the policy is. Do you mean the policy for example, triggering alarms at certain cpu percentage?

yes, monitoring and triggering alarm is one part, and tacking action on the basis of that alarm is another part.
We needs to define actions on the basis of triggers. Although I am ok keep it out from the scope of this spec, but at the same time we also needs to plan those for targeted scenarios.
I am wondering if user should modify the VNFD depends on the monitoring target.
Different exporters should be installed depending on the application. If so, does the user re-configure the descriptor for each use case?
I don't understand your question. Please explain more.
Also, It needs a sample VNFD here.
That's a good point Hyunsik. Thanks.
Please update with sample VNFD.
Got it, I will make a sample VNFD as soon as possible, and update this spec.

Do we need to install each exporters inside VDU?
What about cAdviser, Openstack-exporter

Before we discuss it, I think we should make 'what vdu refers in this case'
more clear. There are several cases, but I'll mention two scenarios:
one is 'one vdu = one vnf = one pod', 
another is 'more than one vdu = one vnf = more than one pod'.
#Let's assume one vdu refers one vnf and one pod.

1) Do we need to install each exporters inside VDU?
-> It depends on your scenario, but node exporter should be installed every VDU
. Node exporter exposes information of each VDU to Prometheus, and to monitor 
vms and physical nodes, the exporter is essential.

2) What about cAdviser, Openstack-exporter
-> cAdvisor is not meant to monitor physical nodes or vms. It is in Kubernetes
pod. Simply it is a monitoring agent in the Kubernetes pod to expose its 
metrics. cAdvisor gives container related information. And it runs without 
installation. So we don't need to make any VNFD for cAdvisor. But we'll provide
some manual to give users how to monitor with cAdvisor.
And for Openstack-exporter, it also does not give you any information of VDUs, 
or instances. This exporter monitors holistic OpenStack status. The exporter 
is installed in openstack host, so we don't need VNFD to install it.
You can find some metrics on the readme file. 
(ref1. openstack-exporter :
 https://github.com/att-comdev/prometheus-openstack-exporter)

what is this path?

The path is needed to register new VNFs into Prometheus target.
Prometheus supports file service discovery.
This way, if you write the node you want to monitor to a specific file, Prometheus will read the file and monitor the node.
The advantage of this approach is that when the file is updated, the Prometheus is automatically updated without having to restart the daemon, etc.

Is it supported only with IP v4?

I have followed the documentation from this link https://support.hpe.com/hpesc/public/docDisplay?docId=emr_na-a00016376en_us . I am capturing the relevent part here.

•  Use DHCP to get an IPv4 address on a specific NIC port. 
   For example:
   Shell> sysconfig -s PreBootNetwork=EmbNicPort1 Dhcpv4=Enabled
•  Use IPv6 auto configuration on a specific NIC port. 
   For example:
   Shell> sysconfig -s PreBootNetwork=FlexLom1Port1 Ipv6ConfigPolicy=Automatic

So i think we can enable ipv6 network configuration by choosing "Automatic" or "Manual" and configure the network accordingly.
But is it required now for this patch. If it is required can we handle this in a different patch?
There is a subtle difference. It uses PATCH while we need POST operation.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
"sticky sessions" here is apparently configured via the "balance='source'" directive; docs at: https://www.haproxy.com/documentation/hapee/latest/onepage/#balance.  but these are stateless HTTP services and AFAIK there are no HTTP-session like features.  Per haproxy's docs "This algorithm is generally used in TCP mode where no cookie may be inserted. It may also be used on the Internet to provide a best-effort stickiness to clients which refuse session cookies." neither of which apply here.  why don't we instead remove "balance='source'" ? that way we can leave hash-type at its recommended default of "map-based". 

These services are stateless HTTP servers, the only reason I can think that "stickyness" might be here is to make debugging across multiple log files easier, but this is not a performance strategy, it's a debugging strategy.

if I'm wrong about the "stateless HTTP" aspect here and there's some kind of important session cookie type of thing that is occurring (w/ a web service?), let me know.
Great point, thank you. Changing from sticky to generic LB is not that I wanted to address here though... It may be worth discussing in some mail thread and come up with a follow up?

manifests/haproxy.pp.message: Though I don't see any issues with changing this from round-robin to leastconn, not sure why it was changed for heat_api_cfn and not for heat_api?  heat_api is the main api endpoint, heat_api_cfn is only used only for AWS resources and some signaling.

I should change it for both then. After a quick sight on the API/CFN docs, my impression was that only the latter has the "notion of long running HTTP sessions". So I'll fix that in a follow-up, thanks.

Since we're potentially changing this, I think a parameter should be introduced for these balance options, because let's face it, we do not have a 100% grip on corner cases that might be affected by this and having a quick way to revert back things will be good to have, since we're changing it

nit: we could have this check outside the ifs conditions since we only invoke this method for these two events anyway (AFTER_CREATE, BEFORE_DELETE).

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/736386/4/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/mech_driver.py@203
yes, but that wouldn't change anything in fact. In case of BEFORE_DELETE, there is no full rule given never in kwargs so it will always need to retrieve it from db in such case.

nit: the footprint is a bit confusing maybe. You want to determine of the SG has rules with same normalized cidr and you pass in a sg_rule. Maybe it's clearer if you pass in the sg_id and the remote_ip_prefix ?
gotcha! Thanks :)
In fact I need sg_rule to be passed here as I need to compare also other keys, like direction, port range, protocol, etc. if normalized_cidr is the same.

I realize that this is one of the stated goals of the patch, but if we are trying to delete a rule, and the SG has rules that have different, but equivalent remote_ip_prefix, why don't we want to go ahead and delete it? Am I reading that right?

imagine the case when user adds 2 rules to SG, one with e.g. cidr 10.10.10.175/26 and second with same attributes, like e.g. protocol, ethertype and others but with cidr 10.10.10.128/26. After this patch OF rules for those 2 rules will effectively be added only once on the host and when one of them will be removed, Neutron will build acl for this rule and will remove flows. So without this check it would remove OF for both those rules and there would be "mismatch" between what is in Neutron DB and on the backend as there would be rule to allow traffic from e.g. 10.10.10.128/26 in db but it wouldn't be on the compute.

So that's why there is this check here.

Ok, got it. Thanks! I'd like to put my vote in for neutron not allowing the creation of *both* rules. I get that for backward compatibility we can't just do the no host bits thing. But I don't see any good reason to allow the creation of 2 identical rules.

nit:

return not any(rule1.get(key) != rule2.get(key) for key in compare_keys)
Done
ack
value is kind of important because it may happen that rule has 'remote_ip_prefix' but with value None or empty string and in such case we don't need to process it more.

-1: This commit message doesn't seem right.

While refactoring the iSCSI code I did extensive testing setting "find_multipaths=yes", even dropping more than 10% of the network traffic, and this was NEVER an issue.

This may be related to something else, and the patch may be fixing it, but we definitely need a better explanation of WHY it is not generating the right links.

udev rules for the generation of by-id links should be independent of multipath.

I am not suffering it, I used the log extracts from the bug report to forcefully get into the same situation.
The fact that it didn't happen for *you* with find_multipaths set to no is not significant.  In the same way that the bug   never happening to me in all my extensive testing of the os-brick iSCSI code is not significant either.

I added a comment on the LP bug on how find_multipaths actually work, because you are mistaken.  Truth be told, the choosing of the configuration option and what it does when set to "no" is terrible, and you are not the first one getting confused by it.

As indicated in the bug report I think you are suffering a different issue. The system is not loaded and this does not happen with find_multipaths no.

Also your statement is not correct, if 'find_multipaths' is set to 'no', we can't be in a situation where a multipath device is created before the individual volumes appear under sysfs '/dev/disk/by-id/scsi-*'. Since multipathd will *never* create one for us automatically. That will be done by os-brick [0]

[0] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/master/os_brick/initiator/connectors/iscsi.py#L751

Hello Gorka, Thanks a lot for your inputs on this patch.

I sent a email to the mailing list [0] with reproducing steps (really easy to reproduce), also you can find the bug reported here [1] which basically looks to really follow what the behavior is when find_multipath is set to yes.

An other important point. During my tests I noticed that to have the changes in option find_multipath well took into account I had to reboot the server. Restarting the service was not enough (You might know the reasons).

But basically the first time you attach the volume the process is working well since multipathd did not have in /etc/multipath/wwid registered the wwid, then the second time the issue occurs since the wiid is in the whitelist, multipathd automatically creates the mpath.

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003618.html
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-nova-compute/+bug/1815844

I read the bug report before reviewing the code, and it doesn't sound too reasonable.  udev rules should always get triggered, regardless of the multipath part, and symlinks should be added not only on the first time the device is added.

If you had to reboot the system for multipathd to use the options there are 3 possibilities:
- There is a bug in the multipathd binary from you distro (it works fine with Fedora, Centos, and RHEL).
- The service didn't actually restart
- The service restarted, the config changes took effect, but you missed it (this has happened to me before with other services).

I have updated the bug with an RCA that explains why this is happening.  In summary, it is a race condition between the detection and the udev triggering that happens on backends that have multiple designators on page 0x83 when the CPU usage is high.  It will happen with "find_multipaths no" as well.

Using `get_dm_name` may or may NOT return the wwn. As the method says it returns the name, it doesn't say it returns the wwn, so you may get something like "mpathb" instead.

The iSCSI code is non-trivial, and takes into consideration many different multipathd configurations as well as possible iSCSI issues, so changes must be carefully thought so we don't introduce issues we are already aware of, so I'm ok with you looking for an alternative that pleases everyone, after all this is your patch, and I will not submit my code changes in an alternative patch to compete with yours.

kernel-modules/intel-i40e/centos/build_s.message: Maybe somebody who understands this stuff better than me can comment on whether or not those commit ids need to be changed if we want the first iteration of this to show up as 1.

The BASE_SRCREV_FOR_PATH paths are correct.  They must point to the kernel sub-directories.  The goal is to have this kmod auto-uprev and auto compile when the kernel changes.  The selected SHA is good.  This was the most recent change to the kernels.

A complete reset of these values for upversioning the package would be to set to the HEAD for each of the respective dirs, in the current branch. The counts are done with a local "git rev-list --count. See:
https://opendev.org/starlingx/root/src/commit/0c7d394f60ed3870c8bf7bea48ed3d7a4da579e7/build-tools/srpm-utils#L3192

In this case, the .gitreview does not impact these versions, as each of these is based on the rev-list count in the respective dirs.

.gitreview updates will only impact a version that's using GITREVCOUNT, based on the full repo, I believe.

If we're upversioning a kernel module, we can set PKG_BASE_SRCREV to the HEAD SHA at this point. Same is true for the BASE_SRCREV_FOR_PATH values... set to the HEAD sha for the kernel-std and kernel-rt directories, respectively. Each of these values is independent, but could be the same value for each if that commit touched each dir.

I think what's being asked to do is change the BASE_SRCREV_FOR_PATH to intel-i40e and intel-iavf, if I understand correctly instead of based on the kernel?

I'm disabling the "multiple share replicas" test case for this driver [1]. The test is written in a way to find three pools in a replication domain and create a share with two replicas. That assumption holds good with this driver, however, the test wants to:

1) Create a share in AZ1
2) Create a replica in AZ2
3) Create another replica in AZ2

We setup this driver with three pools between two backends [2]. Lets say we assign AZ1 to backend "alpha" which has two pools (alpha0 and beta0), and we have a backend called "gamma" in AZ2 which has one pool (gamma0)

We create a share in a random pool to begin with... so, If the share gets created on  alpha (a backend with two pools), creating a replica on AZ2 succeeds, but creating a third replica always fails, in the scheduler, because the test seeks to put two replicas in AZ2, while there is only one pool in that AZ.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/manila-tempest-plugin/src/commit/a3b6f7ad25fcb8b97915cfad27effaf0d350dbe7/manila_tempest_tests/tests/api/test_replication.py#L224-L253

My first patchsets were using ansible ssl modules. I've reverted back to shell modules.
2 reasons for that:
- we want to backport that stuff down to queens, and some ansible SSL modules (openssl_certificate_info) are not supported in previous ansible releases. So I tried to write tasks that could be run in any tripleo/ansible release.
- some tasks are not feasible in ansible: for instance, the task you highlight there updates the cipher of a private key (it means that the "new" private key is still valid for previously generated certificates), the ansible SSL module only supports creating new private keys.

bsp-files/kickstarts/pre_disk_setup_tail.message:
I'm kind of anti-'sleep' as it just masks problems. I'd like to see something more deterministic. 

Per the systemd doc:

After the operation is complete the partitioner/formatter can simply close the device node. This has two effects: it implicitly releases the lock, so that `systemd-udevd` can process events on the device node again. Secondly, it results an `IN_CLOSE` event, which causes `systemd-udevd` to immediately re-process the device — seeing all changes the tool made — and notify subscribed clients about it.

From this, the closing of the FDs and then the settle should be sufficient. Or consider an explicit 'udevadm trigger--type=devices <dev> for each $STOR_DEV prior to the settle if you want to force it.
OK. Seems like we need to validate this better if this is a concern or make it longer than 2 seconds.

The 'IN_CLOSE' may be immediate but the partition rescan sent back by udev to the kernel is not instantaneous and I don't trust the trigger so out of paranoia sleep will remain here, is not in a loop or anything so 2s delay out of 20m is ok.

I think the flow goes like this: udev has inotify on all devices, it receives the IN_CLOSE event then it sends back a BLKRRPART which triggers kernel to shuffle all devnodes through devtmpfs. Then, once nodes are recreated, udev updates the links in /dev/disk/by-path/.
So practically we have two kernel events.

After kernel sends the IN_CLOSE it switches to the next process so udev starts running in the background. If the next task is 'udevadm settle' then we will wait till BLKRRPART reaches the kernel but we don't know when devtmpfs flushes all devices! So we can wait for the fist kernel event but not for the second, as we don't know when devtmpfs finishes its work. This is in line with what we observed => a udevadm trigger won't help here.

I may be wrong but won't take the risk for 2s once in the lifetime of the install :)

From an uber paranoia perspective... The default timeout here is 2 minutes. Consider running this as 'timeout 119 udevadm settle'. If exit status is 124, then either bail out as something is wrong OR trigger some additional validation

OK. I was hoping to avoid the case of a udev hang after reading about a few instances of it in anaconda on questionable H/W. But it would probably likely hang upon earlier partitioning commands if we had a faulty disk.

[anaconda root@localhost ~]# timeout
-bash: timeout: command not found
case closed :).

I'll add a check and abort in case of any udevadm settle error code as we don't expect any here.
